content.title: Fibromuscular Dysplasia - Comprehensive Overview
content.summary: Non-atherosclerotic, non-inflammatory arterial disease affecting medium-sized vessels, most commonly renal and carotid arteries, predominantly in young to middle-aged women.

definitions.definition: Idiopathic, segmental, non-atherosclerotic, non-inflammatory disease of the arterial wall, causing stenosis, aneurysm, or dissection of small to medium-sized arteries.
Most common type (>90%), affecting the media, producing the classic 'string of beads' appearance on angiography.

key_concepts.explanation: Renal arteries most common (60-75%), followed by carotid/vertebral (25-30%), then visceral, iliac, and extremity arteries. Multi-vessel involvement is common (>50%).
String of beads: alternating stenoses and dilations in medial FMD. Focal stenosis: smooth, solitary stenosis (intimal FMD). May also see aneurysms, dissections, and tortuosity.
Renovascular hypertension (renal FMD). TIA/stroke (carotid/vertebral FMD). Headache, pulsatile tinnitus (cranial FMD). May be discovered incidentally or after spontaneous dissection.

Renal FMD: balloon angioplasty without stent (high success rate). Carotid FMD: medical management for asymptomatic; intervention for symptomatic disease. Antiplatelet therapy for all. Screening for multi-vessel involvement recommended.

evidence.citation: US FMD Registry, Olin et al., 2012
evidence.finding: Multivessel FMD present in >50% of patients; screening of other vascular beds recommended at diagnosis
Balloon angioplasty for renal FMD achieves blood pressure improvement in 70-80% with low restenosis rates

clinical_pearls: Consider FMD in young patients (especially women) with hypertension, stroke, or spontaneous dissection
String of beads appearance is classic but not universal - focal stenosis can also be FMD
Stenting is NOT routinely performed for renal FMD - balloon angioplasty alone is preferred
Screen for intracranial aneurysms (12% prevalence) - MRA of brain recommended
FMD can be associated with spontaneous coronary artery dissection (SCAD)
learning_objectives: Describe the arterial distribution of fibromuscular dysplasia
Recognize classic imaging findings of FMD
Explain why stenting is avoided in renal FMD
Outline screening recommendations for multi-vessel involvement
